23.verse: “LORD, keep the promise forever that you made about my family and me, your servant. Do what you have said.

24.verse: Then you will be honored always, and people will say, ‘The LORD All-Powerful, the God over Israel, is Israel’s God!’ And the family of your servant David will continue before you.

25.verse: “My God, you have told me that you would make my family great. So I, your servant, am brave enough to pray to you.

26.verse: LORD, you are God, and you have promised these good things to me, your servant.

27.verse: You have chosen to bless my family. Let it continue before you always. LORD, you have blessed my family, so it will always be blessed.”

1.verse: David Defeats Nations - Later, David defeated the Philistines, conquered them, and took the city of Gath and the small towns around it.

2.verse: He also defeated the people of Moab. So the people of Moab became servants of David and gave him the payment he demanded.

3.verse: David also defeated Hadadezer king of Zobah all the way to the town of Hamath as he tried to spread his kingdom to the Euphrates River.

4.verse: David captured one thousand of his chariots, seven thousand men who rode in chariots, and twenty thousand foot soldiers. He crippled all but a hundred of the chariot horses.

5.verse: Arameans from Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, but David killed twenty-two thousand of them.

6.verse: Then David put groups of soldiers in Damascus in Aram. The Arameans became David’s servants and gave him the payments he demanded. So the LORD gave David victory everywhere he went.

7.verse: David took the shields of gold that had belonged to Hadadezer’s officers and brought them to Jerusalem.

8.verse: David also took many things made of bronze from Tebah and Cun, which had been cities under Hadadezer’s control. Later, Solomon used this bronze to make things for the Temple: the large bronze bowl, which was called the Sea, the pillars, and other bronze utensils.

9.verse: Toi king of Hamath heard that David had defeated all the army of Hadadezer king of Zobah.

10.verse: So Toi sent his son Hadoram to greet and congratulate King David for defeating Hadadezer. (Hadadezer had been at war with Toi.) Hadoram brought items made of gold, silver, and bronze.

11.verse: King David gave them to the LORD, along with the silver and gold he had taken from these nations: Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, and Amalek.

12.verse: Abishai son of Zeruiah killed eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.

13.verse: David put groups of soldiers in Edom, and all the Edomites became his servants. The LORD gave David victory everywhere he went.

14.verse: David’s Important Officers - David was king over all of Israel, and he did what was fair and right for all his people.

15.verse: Joab son of Zeruiah was commander over the army. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the recorder.

16.verse: Zadok son of Ahitub and Abiathar son of Ahimelech were priests. Shavsha was the royal secretary.

17.verse: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites. And David’s sons were important officers who served at his side.

1.verse: War with the Ammonites and Arameans - When Nahash king of the Ammonites died, his son became king after him.

2.verse: David said, “Nahash was loyal to me, so I will be loyal to his son Hanun.” So David sent messengers to comfort Hanun about his father’s death. David’s officers went to the land of the Ammonites to comfort Hanun.

3.verse: But the Ammonite leaders said to Hanun, “Do you think David wants to honor your father by sending men to comfort you? No! David sent them to study the land and capture it and spy it out.”

4.verse: So Hanun arrested David’s officers. To shame them he shaved their beards and cut off their clothes at the hips. Then he sent them away.

5.verse: When the people told David what had happened to his officers, he sent messengers to meet them, because they were very ashamed. King David said, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back. Then come home.”

6.verse: The Ammonites knew that they had insulted David. So Hanun and the Ammonites sent about seventy-four thousand pounds of silver to hire chariots and chariot drivers from Northwest Mesopotamia, Aram Maacah, and Zobah.

7.verse: The Ammonites hired thirty-two thousand chariots and the king of Maacah and his army. So they came and set up camp near the town of Medeba. The Ammonites themselves came out of their towns and got ready for battle.

8.verse: When David heard about this, he sent Joab with the whole army.

9.verse: The Ammonites came out and prepared for battle at the city gate. The kings who had come to help were out in the field by themselves.

10.verse: Joab saw that there were enemies both in front of him and behind him. So he chose some of the best soldiers of Israel and sent them out to fight the Arameans.

11.verse: Joab put the rest of the army under the command of Abishai, his brother. Then they went out to fight the Ammonites.

12.verse: Joab said to Abishai, “If the Arameans are too strong for me, you must help me. Or, if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I will help you.

13.verse: Be strong. We must fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God. The LORD will do what he thinks is right.”

14.verse: Then Joab and the army with him went to attack the Arameans, and the Arameans ran away.

15.verse: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans were running away, they also ran away from Joab’s brother Abishai and went back to their city. So Joab went back to Jerusalem.

16.verse: When the Arameans saw that Israel had defeated them, they sent messengers to bring other Arameans from east of the Euphrates River. Their leader was Shophach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army.

17.verse: When David heard about this, he gathered all the Israelites, and they crossed over the Jordan River. He prepared them for battle, facing the Arameans. The Arameans fought with him,

18.verse: but they ran away from the Israelites. David killed seven thousand Aramean chariot drivers and forty thousand Aramean foot soldiers. He also killed Shophach, the commander of the Aramean army.

19.verse: When those who served Hadadezer saw that the Israelites had defeated them, they made peace with David and served him. So the Arameans refused to help the Ammonites again.

1.verse: Joab Destroys the Ammonites - In the spring, the time of year when kings normally went out to battle, Joab led out the army of Israel. But David stayed in Jerusalem. The army of Israel destroyed the land of Ammon and went to the city of Rabbah and attacked it.

2.verse: David took the crown off the head of their king, and had it placed on his own head. That gold crown weighed about seventy-five pounds, and it had valuable gems in it. And David took many valuable things from the city.

3.verse: He also brought out the people of the city and forced them to work with saws, iron picks, and axes. David did this to all the Ammonite cities. Then David and all his army returned to Jerusalem.

4.verse: Philistine Giants Are Killed - Later, at Gezer, war broke out with the Philistines. Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Sippai, who was one of the descendants of the Rephaites. So those Philistines were defeated.

5.verse: Later, there was another battle with the Philistines. Elhanan son of Jair killed Lahmi, the brother of Goliath, who was from the town of Gath. His spear was as large as a weaver’s rod.

6.verse: At Gath another battle took place. A huge man was there; he had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four fingers and toes in all. This man also was one of the sons of Rapha.

7.verse: When he spoke against Israel, Jonathan son of Shimea, David’s brother, killed him.

8.verse: These descendants of Rapha from Gath were killed by David and his men.

1.verse: David Counts the Israelites - Satan was against Israel, and he caused David to count the people of Israel.

2.verse: So David said to Joab and the commanders of the troops, “Go and count all the Israelites from Beersheba to Dan. Then tell me so I will know how many there are.”

3.verse: But Joab said, “May the LORD give the nation a hundred times more people. My master the king, all the Israelites are your servants. Why do you want to do this, my master? You will make Israel guilty of sin.”

4.verse: But the king commanded Joab, so Joab left and went through all Israel. Then he returned to Jerusalem.

5.verse: Joab gave the list of the people to David. There were one million one hundred thousand men in all of Israel who could use the sword, and there were four hundred seventy thousand men in Judah who could use the sword.

6.verse: But Joab did not count the tribes of Levi and Benjamin, because he didn’t like King David’s order.

7.verse: David had done something God had said was wrong, so God punished Israel.

8.verse: Then David said to God, “I have sinned greatly by what I have done! Now, I beg you to forgive me, your servant, because I have been very foolish.”

9.verse: The LORD said to Gad, who was David’s seer,

10.verse: “Go and tell David, ‘This is what the LORD says: I offer you three choices. Choose one of them and I will do it.’”

11.verse: So Gad went to David and said to him, “This is what the LORD says: ‘Choose for yourself

12.verse: three years of hunger. Or choose three months of running from your enemies as they chase you with their swords. Or choose three days of punishment from the LORD, in which a terrible disease will spread through the country. The angel of the LORD will go through Israel destroying the people.’ Now, David, decide which of these things I should tell the LORD who sent me.”

13.verse: David said to Gad, “I am in great trouble. Let the LORD punish me, because the LORD is very merciful. Don’t let my punishment come from human beings.”

14.verse: So the LORD sent a terrible disease on Israel, and seventy thousand people died.

15.verse: God sent an angel to destroy Jerusalem, but when the angel started to destroy it, the LORD saw it and felt very sorry about the terrible things that had happened. So he said to the angel who was destroying, “That is enough! Put down your arm!” The angel of the LORD was then standing at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

16.verse: David looked up and saw the angel of the LORD in the sky, holding his sword drawn and pointed at Jerusalem. Then David and the elders bowed facedown on the ground. They were wearing rough cloth to show their grief.

17.verse: David said to God, “I am the one who sinned and did wrong. I gave the order for the people to be counted. These people only followed me like sheep. They did nothing wrong. LORD my God, please punish me and my family, but stop the terrible disease that is killing your people.”

18.verse: Then the angel of the LORD told Gad to tell David that he should build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

19.verse: So David did what Gad told him to do, in the name of the LORD.

20.verse: Araunah was separating the wheat from the straw. When he turned around, he saw the angel. Araunah’s four sons who were with him hid.

21.verse: David came to Araunah, and when Araunah saw him, he left the threshing floor and bowed facedown on the ground before David.

22.verse: David said to him, “Sell me your threshing floor so I can build an altar to the LORD here. Then the terrible disease will stop. Sell it to me for the full price.”

23.verse: Araunah said to David, “Take this threshing floor. My master the king, do anything you want. Look, I will also give you oxen for the whole burnt offerings, the threshing boards for the wood, and wheat for the grain offering. I give everything to you.”

24.verse: But King David answered Araunah, “No, I will pay the full price for the land. I won’t take anything that is yours and give it to the LORD. I won’t offer a burnt offering that costs me nothing.”

25.verse: So David paid Araunah about fifteen pounds of gold for the place.

26.verse: David built an altar to the LORD there and offered whole burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. David prayed to the LORD, and he answered him by sending down fire from heaven on the altar of burnt offering.

27.verse: Then the LORD commanded the angel to put his sword back into its holder.

28.verse: When David saw that the LORD had answered him on the threshing floor of Araunah, he offered sacrifices there.

29.verse: The Holy Tent that Moses made while the Israelites were in the desert and the altar of burnt offerings were in Gibeon at the place of worship.

30.verse: But David could not go to the Holy Tent to speak with God, because he was afraid of the angel of the LORD and his sword.

1.verse: David said, “The Temple of the LORD God and the altar for Israel’s burnt offerings will be built here.”

2.verse: David Makes Plans for the Temple - So David ordered all foreigners living in Israel to gather together. From that group David chose stonecutters to cut stones to be used in building the Temple of God.

3.verse: David supplied a large amount of iron to be used for making nails and hinges for the gate doors. He also supplied more bronze than could be weighed,

4.verse: and he supplied more cedar logs than could be counted. Much of the cedar had been brought to David by the people from Sidon and Tyre.

5.verse: David said, “We should build a great Temple for the LORD, which will be famous everywhere for its greatness and beauty. But my son Solomon is young. He hasn’t yet learned what he needs to know, so I will prepare for the building of it.” So David got many of the materials ready before he died.

6.verse: Then David called for his son Solomon and told him to build the Temple for the LORD, the God of Israel.

7.verse: David said to him, “My son, I wanted to build a temple for worshiping the LORD my God.

8.verse: But the LORD spoke his word to me, ‘David, you have killed many people. You have fought many wars. You cannot build a temple for worship to me, because you have killed many people.

9.verse: But, you will have a son, a man of peace and rest. I will give him rest from all his enemies around him. His name will be Solomon, and I will give Israel peace and quiet while he is king.

10.verse: Solomon will build a temple for worship to me. He will be my son, and I will be his father. I will make his kingdom strong; someone from his family will rule Israel forever.’”

11.verse: David said, “Now, my son, may the LORD be with you. May you build a temple for the LORD your God, as he said you would.

12.verse: He will make you the king of Israel. May the LORD give you wisdom and understanding so you will be able to obey the teachings of the LORD your God.

13.verse: Be careful to obey the rules and laws the LORD gave Moses for Israel. If you obey them, you will have success. Be strong and brave. Don’t be afraid or discouraged.

14.verse: “Solomon, I have worked hard getting many of the materials for building the Temple of the LORD. I have supplied about seven and one-half million pounds of gold, about seventy-five million pounds of silver, so much bronze and iron it cannot be weighed, and wood and stone. You may add to them.

15.verse: You have many workmen—stonecutters, bricklayers, carpenters, and people skilled in every kind of work.

16.verse: They are skilled in working with gold, silver, bronze, and iron. You have more craftsmen than can be counted. Now begin the work, and may the LORD be with you.”

17.verse: Then David ordered all the leaders of Israel to help his son Solomon.

18.verse: David said to them, “The LORD your God is with you. He has given you rest from our enemies. He has handed over to me the people living around us. The LORD and his people are in control of this land.

19.verse: Now give yourselves completely to obeying the LORD your God. Build the holy place of the LORD God; build the Temple for worship to the LORD. Then bring the Ark of the Agreement with the LORD and the holy items that belong to God into the Temple.”

1.verse: The Levites - After David had lived long and was old, he made his son Solomon the new king of Israel.

2.verse: David gathered all the leaders of Israel, along with the priests and Levites.

3.verse: He counted the Levites who were thirty years old and older. In all, there were thirty-eight thousand Levites.

4.verse: David said, “Of these, twenty-four thousand Levites will direct the work of the Temple of the LORD, six thousand Levites will be officers and judges,

5.verse: four thousand Levites will be gatekeepers, and four thousand Levites will praise the LORD with musical instruments I made for giving praise.”

6.verse: David separated the Levites into three groups that were led by Levi’s three sons: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.

7.verse: The People of Gershon - From the people of Gershon, there were Ladan and Shimei.

8.verse: Ladan had three sons. His first son was Jehiel, and his other sons were Zetham and Joel.

9.verse: Shimei’s sons were Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran. These three sons were leaders of Ladan’s families.

10.verse: Shimei had four sons: Jahath, Ziza, Jeush, and Beriah.

11.verse: Jahath was the first son, and Ziza was the second son. But Jeush and Beriah did not have many children, so they were counted as if they were one family.

12.verse: The People of Kohath - Kohath had four sons: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

13.verse: Amram’s sons were Aaron and Moses. Aaron and his descendants were chosen to be special forever. They were chosen to prepare the holy things for the LORD’s service, to offer sacrifices before the LORD, and to serve him as priests. They were to give blessings in his name forever.

14.verse: Moses was the man of God, and his sons were counted as part of the tribe of Levi.

15.verse: Moses’ sons were Gershom and Eliezer.

16.verse: Gershom’s first son was Shubael.

17.verse: Eliezer’s first son was Rehabiah. Eliezer had no other sons, but Rehabiah had many sons.

18.verse: Izhar’s first son was Shelomith.

19.verse: Hebron’s first son was Jeriah, his second was Amariah, his third was Jahaziel, and his fourth was Jekameam.

20.verse: Uzziel’s first son was Micah and his second was Isshiah.

21.verse: The People of Merari - Merari’s sons were Mahli and Mushi. Mahli’s sons were Eleazar and Kish.

22.verse: Eleazar died without sons; he had only daughters. Eleazar’s daughters married their cousins, the sons of Kish.

23.verse: Mushi’s three sons were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth.

24.verse: The Levites’ Work - These were Levi’s descendants listed by their families. They were the leaders of families. Each person who was twenty years old or older was listed. They served in the LORD’s Temple.

25.verse: David had said, “The LORD, the God of Israel, has given rest to his people. He has come to live in Jerusalem forever.

26.verse: So the Levites don’t need to carry the Holy Tent or any of the things used in its services anymore.”

27.verse: David’s last instructions were to count the Levites who were twenty years old and older.

28.verse: The Levites had the job of helping Aaron’s descendants in the service of the Temple of the LORD. They cared for the Temple courtyard and side rooms, and they made all the holy things pure. Their job was to serve in the Temple of God.

29.verse: They were responsible for putting the holy bread on the table, for the flour in the grain offerings, for the bread made without yeast, for the baking and mixing, and for the measuring.

30.verse: The Levites also stood every morning and gave thanks and praise to the LORD. They also did this every evening.

31.verse: The Levites offered all the burnt offerings to the LORD on the special days of rest, at the New Moon festivals, and at all appointed feasts. They served before the LORD every day. They were to follow the rules for how many Levites should serve each time.

32.verse: So the Levites took care of the Meeting Tent and the Holy Place. And they helped their relatives, Aaron’s descendants, with the services at the Temple of the LORD.

1.verse: The Groups of the Priests - These were the groups of Aaron’s sons: Aaron’s sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

2.verse: But Nadab and Abihu died before their father did, and they had no sons. So Eleazar and Ithamar served as the priests.

3.verse: David, with the help of Zadok, a descendant of Eleazar, and Ahimelech, a descendant of Ithamar, separated their family groups into two different groups. Each group had certain duties.

4.verse: There were more leaders from Eleazar’s family than from Ithamar’s—sixteen leaders from Eleazar’s family and eight leaders from Ithamar’s family.

5.verse: Men were chosen from Eleazar’s and Ithamar’s families by throwing lots. Some men from each family were chosen to be in charge of the Holy Place, and some were chosen to serve as priests.

6.verse: Shemaiah son of Nethanel, from the tribe of Levi, was the secretary. He recorded the names of those descendants in front of King David, the officers, Zadok the priest, Ahimelech son of Abiathar, and the leaders of the families of the priests and Levites. The work was divided by lots among the families of Eleazar and Ithamar. The following men with their groups were chosen.

7.verse: The first one chosen was Jehoiarib. The second was Jedaiah.

8.verse: The third was Harim. The fourth was Seorim.

9.verse: The fifth was Malkijah. The sixth was Mijamin.

10.verse: The seventh was Hakkoz. The eighth was Abijah.

11.verse: The ninth was Jeshua. The tenth was Shecaniah.

12.verse: The eleventh was Eliashib. The twelfth was Jakim.

13.verse: The thirteenth was Huppah. The fourteenth was Jeshebeab.

14.verse: The fifteenth was Bilgah. The sixteenth was Immer.

15.verse: The seventeenth was Hezir. The eighteenth was Happizzez.

16.verse: The nineteenth was Pethahiah. The twentieth was Jehezkel.

17.verse: The twenty-first was Jakin. The twenty-second was Gamul.

18.verse: The twenty-third was Delaiah. The twenty-fourth was Maaziah.

19.verse: These were the groups chosen to serve in the Temple of the LORD. They obeyed the rules given them by Aaron, just as the LORD, the God of Israel, had commanded him.

20.verse: The Other Levites - These are the names of the rest of Levi’s descendants: Shubael was a descendant of Amram, and Jehdeiah was a descendant of Shubael.

21.verse: Isshiah was the first son of Rehabiah.

22.verse: From the Izhar family group, there was Shelomoth, and Jahath was a descendant of Shelomoth.

23.verse: Hebron’s first son was Jeriah, Amariah was his second, Jahaziel was his third, and Jekameam was his fourth.

24.verse: Uzziel’s son was Micah. Micah’s son was Shamir.

25.verse: Micah’s brother was Isshiah, and Isshiah’s son was Zechariah.

26.verse: Merari’s descendants were Mahli and Mushi. Merari’s son was Jaaziah.

27.verse: Jaaziah son of Merari had sons named Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.

28.verse: Mahli’s son was Eleazar, but Eleazar did not have any sons.

30.verse: Mushi’s sons were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These are the Levites, listed by their families.

31.verse: They were chosen for special jobs by throwing lots in front of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, the leaders of the families of the priests, and the Levites. They did this just as their relatives, the priests, Aaron’s descendants, had done. The families of the oldest brother and the youngest brother were treated the same.

1.verse: The Music Groups - David and the commanders of the army chose some of the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun to preach and play harps, lyres, and cymbals. Here is a list of the men who served in this way:

2.verse: Asaph’s sons who served were Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asarelah. King David chose Asaph to preach, and Asaph directed his sons.

3.verse: Jeduthun’s sons who served were Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah. There were six of them, and Jeduthun directed them. He preached and used a harp to give thanks and praise to the LORD.

4.verse: Heman’s sons who served were Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shubael, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamti-Ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth.

5.verse: All these were sons of Heman, David’s seer. God promised to make Heman strong, so Heman had many sons. God gave him fourteen sons and three daughters.

6.verse: Heman directed all his sons in making music for the Temple of the LORD with cymbals, lyres, and harps; that was their way of serving in the Temple of God. King David was in charge of Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman.

7.verse: These men and their relatives were trained and skilled in making music for the LORD. There were two hundred eighty-eight of them.

8.verse: Everyone threw lots to choose the time his family was to serve at the Temple. The young and the old, the teacher and the student, had to throw lots.

9.verse: First, the lot fell to Joseph, from the family of Asaph. Second, twelve men were chosen from Gedaliah, his sons and relatives.

10.verse: Third, twelve men were chosen from Zaccur, his sons and relatives.

11.verse: Fourth, twelve men were chosen from Izri, his sons and relatives.

12.verse: Fifth, twelve men were chosen from Nethaniah, his sons and relatives.

13.verse: Sixth, twelve men were chosen from Bukkiah, his sons and relatives.

14.verse: Seventh, twelve men were chosen from Jesarelah, his sons and relatives.

15.verse: Eighth, twelve men were chosen from Jeshaiah, his sons and relatives.

16.verse: Ninth, twelve men were chosen from Mattaniah, his sons and relatives.

17.verse: Tenth, twelve men were chosen from Shimei, his sons and relatives.

18.verse: Eleventh, twelve men were chosen from Azarel, his sons and relatives.

19.verse: Twelfth, twelve men were chosen from Hashabiah, his sons and relatives.

20.verse: Thirteenth, twelve men were chosen from Shubael, his sons and relatives.

21.verse: Fourteenth, twelve men were chosen from Mattithiah, his sons and relatives.

22.verse: Fifteenth, twelve men were chosen from Jerimoth, his sons and relatives.

23.verse: Sixteenth, twelve men were chosen from Hananiah, his sons and relatives.

24.verse: Seventeenth, twelve men were chosen from Joshbekashah, his sons and relatives.

25.verse: Eighteenth, twelve men were chosen from Hanani, his sons and relatives.

26.verse: Nineteenth, twelve men were chosen from Mallothi, his sons and relatives.

27.verse: Twentieth, twelve men were chosen from Eliathah, his sons and relatives.

28.verse: Twenty-first, twelve men were chosen from Hothir, his sons and relatives.

29.verse: Twenty-second, twelve men were chosen from Giddalti, his sons and relatives.

30.verse: Twenty-third, twelve men were chosen from Mahazioth, his sons and relatives.

31.verse: Twenty-fourth, twelve men were chosen from Romamti-Ezer, his sons and relatives.

1.verse: The Gatekeepers - These are the groups of the gatekeepers. From the family of Korah, there was Meshelemiah son of Kore, who was from Asaph’s family.

2.verse: Meshelemiah had sons. Zechariah was his first son, Jediael was second, Zebadiah was third, Jathniel was fourth,

3.verse: Elam was fifth, Jehohanan was sixth, and Eliehoenai was seventh.

4.verse: Obed-Edom had sons. Shemaiah was his first son, Jehozabad was second, Joah was third, Sacar was fourth, Nethanel was fifth,

5.verse: Ammiel was sixth, Issachar was seventh, and Peullethai was eighth. God blessed Obed-Edom with children.

6.verse: Obed-Edom’s son Shemaiah also had sons. They were leaders in their father’s family because they were capable men.

7.verse: Shemaiah’s sons were Othni, Rephael, Obed, Elzabad, Elihu, and Semakiah. Elihu, and Semakiah were skilled workers.

8.verse: All these were Obed-Edom’s descendants. They and their sons and relatives were capable men and strong workers. Obed-Edom had sixty-two descendants in all.

9.verse: Meshelemiah had sons and relatives who were skilled workers. In all, there were eighteen.

10.verse: From the Merari family, Hosah had sons. Shimri was chosen to be in charge. Although he was not the oldest son, his father chose him to be in charge.

11.verse: Hilkiah was his second son, Tabaliah was third, and Zechariah was fourth. In all, Hosah had thirteen sons and relatives.

12.verse: These were the leaders of the groups of gatekeepers, and they served in the Temple of the LORD. Their relatives also worked in the Temple.

13.verse: By throwing lots, each family chose a gate to guard. Young and old threw lots.

14.verse: Meshelemiah was chosen by lot to guard the East Gate. Then lots were thrown for Meshelemiah’s son Zechariah. He was a wise counselor and was chosen for the North Gate.

15.verse: Obed-Edom was chosen for the South Gate, and Obed-Edom’s sons were chosen to guard the storehouse.

16.verse: Shuppim and Hosah were chosen for the West Gate and the Shalleketh Gate on the upper road. Guards stood side by side with guards.

17.verse: Six Levites stood guard every day at the East Gate; four Levites stood guard every day at the North Gate; four Levites stood guard every day at the South Gate; and two Levites at a time guarded the storehouse.

18.verse: There were two guards at the western court and four guards on the road to the court.

19.verse: These were the groups of the gatekeepers from the families of Korah and Merari.

20.verse: Other Leaders - Other Levites were responsible for guarding the treasuries of the Temple of God and for the places where the holy items were kept.

21.verse: Ladan was Gershon’s son and the ancestor of several family groups. Jehiel was a leader of one of the family groups.

22.verse: His sons were Zetham and Joel his brother, and they were responsible for the treasuries of the Temple of the LORD.

23.verse: Other leaders were chosen from the family groups of Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

24.verse: Shubael, the descendant of Gershom, who was Moses’ son, was the leader responsible for the treasuries.

25.verse: These were Shubael’s relatives from Eliezer: Eliezer’s son Rehabiah, Rehabiah’s son Jeshaiah, Jeshaiah’s son Joram, Joram’s son Zicri, and Zicri’s son Shelomith.

26.verse: Shelomith and his relatives were responsible for everything that had been collected for the Temple by King David, by the heads of families, by the commanders of a thousand men and of a hundred men, and by other army commanders.

27.verse: They also gave some of the things they had taken in wars to be used in repairing the Temple of the LORD.

28.verse: Shelomith and his relatives took care of all the holy items. Some had been given by Samuel the seer, Saul son of Kish, Abner son of Ner, and Joab son of Zeruiah.

29.verse: Kenaniah was from the Izhar family. He and his sons worked outside the Temple as officers and judges in different places in Israel.

30.verse: Hashabiah was from the Hebron family. He and his relatives were responsible for the LORD’s work and the king’s business in Israel west of the Jordan River. There were seventeen hundred skilled men in Hashabiah’s group.

31.verse: The history of the Hebron family shows that Jeriah was their leader. In David’s fortieth year as king, the records were searched, and some capable men of the Hebron family were found living at Jazer in Gilead.

32.verse: Jeriah had twenty-seven hundred relatives who were skilled men and leaders of families. King David gave them the responsibility of directing the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and East Manasseh in God’s work and the king’s business.

1.verse: Army Divisions - This is the list of the Israelites who served the king in the army. Each division was on duty one month each year. There were leaders of families, commanders of a hundred men, commanders of a thousand men, and other officers. Each division had twenty-four thousand men.

2.verse: Jashobeam son of Zabdiel was in charge of the first division for the first month. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

3.verse: Jashobeam, one of the descendants of Perez, was leader of all the army officers for the first month.

4.verse: Dodai, from the Ahohites, was in charge of the division for the second month. Mikloth was a leader in the division. There were twenty-four thousand men in Dodai’s division.

5.verse: The third commander, for the third month, was Benaiah son of Jehoiada the priest. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

6.verse: He was the Benaiah who was one of the Thirty soldiers. Benaiah was a brave warrior who led those men. Benaiah’s son Ammizabad was in charge of Benaiah’s division.

7.verse: The fourth commander, for the fourth month, was Asahel, the brother of Joab. Later, Asahel’s son Zebadiah took his place as commander. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

8.verse: The fifth commander, for the fifth month, was Shamhuth, from Izrah’s family. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

9.verse: The sixth commander, for the sixth month, was Ira son of Ikkesh from the town of Tekoa. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

10.verse: The seventh commander, for the seventh month, was Helez. He was from the Pelonites and a descendant of Ephraim. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

11.verse: The eighth commander, for the eighth month, was Sibbecai. He was from Hushah and was from Zerah’s family. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

12.verse: The ninth commander, for the ninth month, was Abiezer. He was from Anathoth in Benjamin. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

13.verse: The tenth commander, for the tenth month, was Maharai. He was from Netophah and was from Zerah’s family. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

14.verse: The eleventh commander, for the eleventh month, was Benaiah. He was from Pirathon in Ephraim. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

15.verse: The twelfth commander, for the twelfth month, was Heldai. He was from Netophah and was from Othniel’s family. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

16.verse: Leaders of the Tribes - These were the leaders of the tribes of Israel. Eliezer son of Zicri was over the tribe of Reuben. Shephatiah son of Maacah was over the tribe of Simeon.

17.verse: Hashabiah son of Kemuel was over the tribe of Levi. Zadok was over the people of Aaron.

18.verse: Elihu, one of David’s brothers, was over the tribe of Judah. Omri son of Michael was over the tribe of Issachar.

19.verse: Ishmaiah son of Obadiah was over the tribe of Zebulun. Jerimoth son of Azriel was over the tribe of Naphtali.

20.verse: Hoshea son of Azaziah was over the tribe of Ephraim. Joel son of Pedaiah was over West Manasseh.

21.verse: Iddo son of Zechariah was over East Manasseh. Jaasiel son of Abner was over the tribe of Benjamin.

22.verse: Azarel son of Jeroham was over the tribe of Dan. These were the leaders of the tribes of Israel.

23.verse: The LORD had promised to make the Israelites as many as the stars in the sky. So David only counted the men who were twenty years old and older.

24.verse: Joab son of Zeruiah began to count the people, but he did not finish. God became angry with Israel for counting the people, so the number of the people was not put in the history book about King David’s rule.

25.verse: The King’s Directors - Azmaveth son of Adiel was in charge of the royal storehouses. Jonathan son of Uzziah was in charge of the storehouses in the country, towns, villages, and towers.

26.verse: Ezri son of Kelub was in charge of the field workers who farmed the land.

27.verse: Shimei, from the town of Ramah, was in charge of the vineyards. Zabdi, from Shapham, was in charge of storing the wine that came from the vineyards.

28.verse: Baal-Hanan, from Geder, was in charge of the olive trees and sycamore trees in the western hills. Joash was in charge of storing the olive oil.

29.verse: Shitrai, from Sharon, was in charge of the herds that fed in the Plain of Sharon. Shaphat son of Adlai was in charge of the herds in the valleys.

30.verse: Obil, an Ishmaelite, was in charge of the camels. Jehdeiah, from Meronoth, was in charge of the donkeys.

31.verse: Jaziz, from the Hagrites, was in charge of the flocks. All these men were the officers who took care of King David’s property.

32.verse: Jonathan was David’s uncle, and he advised David. Jonathan was a wise man and a teacher of the law. Jehiel son of Hacmoni took care of the king’s sons.

33.verse: Ahithophel advised the king. Hushai, from the Arkite people, was the king’s friend.

34.verse: Jehoiada and Abiathar later took Ahithophel’s place in advising the king. Jehoiada was Benaiah’s son. Joab was the commander of the king’s army.

1.verse: David’s Plans for the Temple - David commanded all the leaders of Israel to come to Jerusalem. There were the leaders of the tribes, commanders of the divisions serving the king, commanders of a thousand men and of a hundred men, leaders who took care of the property and animals that belonged to the king and his sons, men over the palace, the powerful men, and all the brave warriors.

2.verse: King David stood up and said, “Listen to me, my relatives and my people. I wanted to build a place to keep the Ark of the Agreement with the LORD. I wanted it to be God’s footstool. So I made plans to build a temple.

3.verse: But God said to me, ‘You must not build a temple for worshiping me, because you are a soldier and have killed many people.’

4.verse: “But the LORD, the God of Israel, chose me from my whole family to be king of Israel forever. He chose the tribe of Judah to lead, and from the people of Judah, he chose my father’s family. From that family God was pleased to make me king of Israel.

5.verse: The LORD has given me many sons, and from those sons he has chosen Solomon to be the new king of Israel. Israel is the LORD’s kingdom.

6.verse: The LORD said to me, ‘Your son Solomon will build my Temple and its courtyards. I have chosen Solomon to be my son, and I will be his father.

7.verse: He is obeying my laws and commands now. If he continues to obey them, I will make his kingdom strong forever.’”

8.verse: David said, “Now, in front of all Israel, the assembly of the LORD, and in the hearing of God, I tell you these things: Be careful to obey all the commands of the LORD your God. Then you will keep this good land and pass it on to your descendants forever.

9.verse: “And you, my son Solomon, accept the God of your father. Serve him completely and willingly, because the LORD knows what is in everyone’s mind. He understands everything you think. If you go to him for help, you will get an answer. But if you turn away from him, he will leave you forever.

10.verse: Solomon, you must understand this. The LORD has chosen you to build the Temple as his holy place. Be strong and finish the job.”

11.verse: Then David gave his son Solomon the plans for building the Temple and the courtyard around the Temple. They included its buildings, its storerooms, its upper rooms, its inside rooms, and the place where the people’s sins were removed.

12.verse: David gave him plans for everything he had in mind: the courtyards around the LORD’s Temple and all the rooms around it, the Temple treasuries, and the treasuries of the holy items used in the Temple.

13.verse: David gave Solomon directions for the groups of the priests and Levites. David told him about all the work of serving in the Temple of the LORD and about the items to be used in the Temple service

14.verse: that were made of gold or silver. David told Solomon how much gold or silver should be used to make each thing.

15.verse: David told him how much gold to use for each gold lampstand and its lamps and how much silver to use for each silver lampstand and its lamps. The different lampstands were to be used where needed.

16.verse: David told how much gold should be used for each table that held the holy bread and how much silver should be used for the silver tables.

17.verse: He told how much pure gold should be used to make the forks, bowls, and pitchers and how much gold should be used to make each gold dish. He told how much silver should be used to make each silver dish

18.verse: and how much pure gold should be used for the altar of incense. He also gave Solomon the plans for the chariot of the golden creatures that spread their wings over the Ark of the Agreement with the LORD.

19.verse: David said, “All these plans were written with the LORD guiding me. He helped me understand everything in the plans.”

20.verse: David also said to his son Solomon, “Be strong and brave, and do the work. Don’t be afraid or discouraged, because the LORD God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you or leave you until all the work for the Temple of the LORD is finished.

21.verse: The groups of the priests and Levites are ready for all the work on the Temple of God. Every skilled worker is ready to help you with all the work. The leaders and all the people will obey every command you give.”

1.verse: Gifts for Building the Temple - King David said to all the Israelites who were gathered, “God chose my son Solomon, who is young and hasn’t yet learned what he needs to know, but the work is important. This palace is not for people; it is for the LORD God.

2.verse: I have done my best to prepare for building the Temple of God. I have given gold for the things made of gold and silver for the things made of silver. I have given bronze for the things made of bronze and iron for the things made of iron. I have given wood for the things made of wood and onyx for the settings. I have given turquoise gems of many different colors, valuable stones, and white marble. I have given much of all these things.

3.verse: I have already given this for the Temple, but now I am also giving my own treasures of gold and silver, because I really want the Temple of my God to be built.

4.verse: I have given about two hundred twenty thousand pounds of pure gold from Ophir and about five hundred twenty thousand pounds of pure silver. They will be used to cover the walls of the buildings

5.verse: and for all the gold and silver work. Skilled men may use the gold and silver to make things for the Temple. Now, who is ready to give himself to the service of the LORD today?”

6.verse: The family leaders and the leaders of the tribes of Israel, the commanders of a thousand men and of a hundred men, and the leaders responsible for the king’s work gave their valuable things.

7.verse: They donated about three hundred eighty thousand pounds of gold, about seven hundred fifty thousand pounds of silver, about one million three hundred fifty thousand pounds of bronze, and about seven million five hundred thousand pounds of iron to the Temple of God.

8.verse: People who had valuable gems gave them to the treasury of the Temple of the LORD, and Jehiel, from the Gershon family, took care of the valuable gems.

9.verse: The leaders gave willingly and completely to the LORD. The people rejoiced to see their leaders give so gladly, and King David was also very happy.

10.verse: David’s Prayer - David praised the LORD in front of all the people who were gathered. He said: “We praise you, LORD, God of our father Israel. We praise you forever and ever.

11.verse: LORD, you are great and powerful. You have glory, victory, and honor. Everything in heaven and on earth belongs to you. The kingdom belongs to you, LORD; you are the ruler over everything.

12.verse: Riches and honor come from you. You rule everything. You have the power and strength to make anyone great and strong.

13.verse: Now, our God, we thank you and praise your glorious name.

14.verse: “These things did not really come from me and my people. Everything comes from you; we have given you back what you gave us.

15.verse: We are like foreigners and strangers, as our ancestors were. Our time on earth is like a shadow. There is no hope.

16.verse: LORD our God, we have gathered all this to build your Temple for worship to you. But everything has come from you; everything belongs to you.

17.verse: I know, my God, that you test people’s hearts. You are happy when people do what is right. I was happy to give all these things, and I gave with an honest heart. Your people gathered here are happy to give to you, and I rejoice to see their giving.

18.verse: LORD, you are the God of our ancestors, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Make your people want to serve you always, and make them want to obey you.

19.verse: Give my son Solomon a desire to serve you. Help him always obey your commands, laws, and rules. Help him build the Temple for which I have prepared.”

20.verse: Then David said to all the people who were gathered, “Praise the LORD your God.” So they all praised the LORD, the God of their ancestors, and they bowed to the ground to give honor to the LORD and the king.

21.verse: Solomon Becomes King - The next day the people sacrificed to the LORD. They offered burnt offerings to him of a thousand bulls, a thousand male sheep, and a thousand male lambs. They also brought drink offerings. Many sacrifices were made for all the people of Israel.

22.verse: That day the people ate and drank with much joy, and the LORD was with them. And they made David’s son Solomon king for the second time. They poured olive oil on Solomon to appoint him king in the presence of the LORD. And they poured oil on Zadok to appoint him as priest.

23.verse: Then Solomon sat on the LORD’s throne as king and took his father David’s place. Solomon was very successful, and all the people of Israel obeyed him.

24.verse: All the leaders and soldiers and King David’s sons accepted Solomon as king and promised to obey him.

25.verse: The LORD made Solomon great before all the Israelites and gave Solomon much honor. No king of Israel before Solomon had such honor.

26.verse: David’s Death - David son of Jesse was king over all Israel.

27.verse: He had ruled over Israel forty years—seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.

28.verse: David died when he was old. He had lived a good, long life and had received many riches and honors. His son Solomon became king after him.

29.verse: Everything David did as king, from beginning to end, is recorded in the records of Samuel the seer, the records of Nathan the prophet, and the records of Gad the seer.

30.verse: Those writings tell what David did as king of Israel. They tell about his power and what happened to him and to Israel and to all the kingdoms around them.
